Author: Ageless#1459

Author: Stani#3346
Content: no no, they are making as even the one transaction in one block genertes fees in flash loans

Author: Stani#3346
Content: Here is a good detail on fees: https://app.aave.com/faq#cost-service

Author: Stani#3346
Content: The platform has 2 type of fees. From borrowers, a 0.25% of the loan amount is collected on loan origination, from which 20% is used for referral integrators and 80% is swapped to LEND token and burned. From flash loans, a 0.35% is collected from the loan amount, from which 90% is redirected as extra income for depositors of the protocol and 10% is splitted using the same 20%/80% model of the origination fee. There also exist transaction fees related with the Ethereum Blockchain usage, these fees depend on the network status and transaction complexity.

Author: pabloaave
Content:
Initially was decided to take different popular and well known tokens also normally with good liquidity etc. We did a risk assesment with the addition to decide the parameters of each token:
https://developers.aave.com/#risk-parameters-matrix

In general new assets addition will come with the implementation of our governance through LEND token. So LEND holders would be able to vote and propose on new additions, in this case new assets to add, their parameters etc

Author: pabloaave
Content: The work began along with the release of the protocol, the idea is have more details in the coming 4-8 weeks but in my honest opinion its better to not give specific ETA etc to avoid expectations on the timing etc. We need to work daily based on the priorities that are coming. If for some reason we notice its required to move to improve the user experience or other thing from the platform and it needs to be done asap we would need to do that. So its not realistic to give a time frame, we need to work on what is priority for the protocol

Author: pabloaave
Content: We are transparent, we are working on the governance for the next phase on the protocol but its not worth to discuss on specific details when they are probable to change as those are still a work in progress, as soon as we release specific documentation with further details we would be able to discuss in more detail

Content:
So a staker earns: 
1) inflationary reward
2) protocol fees 

The staker can then either: 
1) withdraw their earned fees and take them as earnings 
2) reinvest their earned fees into the backstop. Those earnings entered into the backstop then continue to earn fees 

Correct?

Author: Stani#3346
Content: @joeismyname the feedback look idea is to price the inflation/incentive upon protocol grows. The more the protocol grows in debt the more it needs security and the more incentivized the securing the protocol becomes, creating a value loop.

Author: Stani#3346
Content:
> And this graphic implies some kind of relationship between the market cap of LEND and the total pool size? 
> 
> Total market cap of lend = total amount of USD that can be insured in the pools?
@joeismyname In terms of the total market cap of lend = total insured value might not be concrete as the protocol can be partially insured or even same debt capital insured by multiple times depending on the value of LEND market capitalization. What is interesting is that the incentives are like thrust engines that are adjusted based the need for securing the protocol. These incentives drives adoption for obtaining LEND to secure the protocol since there is incentive (inflation/fee sharing)

Author: rb#6109
Content: Hi there, trying to understand the specifics regarding LEND vs aTokens. As I understand it, providing liquidity to a pool gives you a right to that pool's aToken which in turn starts giving you interest right away - that's clear. I can't however find anywhere in the white paper that owning LEND itself gives you a right to the "dividends" of the protocol the same way providing liquidity to individual pools does - owning LEND gives you only voting rights regarding governance. Purely from profit perspective (excluding potential rise in the price of LEND) wouldn't it make sense using my money to provide liquidity to pools instead of buying LEND itself? Am I missing something?

Author: pabloaave
Content:
> Hi there, trying to understand the specifics regarding LEND vs aTokens. As I understand it, providing liquidity to a pool gives you a right to that pool's aToken which in turn starts giving you interest right away - that's clear. I can't however find anywhere in the white paper that owning LEND itself gives you a right to the "dividends" of the protocol the same way providing liquidity to individual pools does - owning LEND gives you only voting rights regarding governance. Purely from profit perspective (excluding potential rise in the price of LEND) wouldn't it make sense using my money to provide liquidity to pools instead of buying LEND itself? Am I missing something?
@rb 
LEND token will be used to govern the protocol, we are currently working on the implementation of the governance apart from this it will be possible to be staked within the protocol to provide security/insurance to the protocol/depositors and that way earn staking rewards and fees from the protocol. Also currently LEND token is burnt based on the fees gathered in the protocol, so holders benefit on the reduction of the supply. We are working to release the specific documentation about tokenomics and governance for more details. Meanwhile this article may be helpful:
https://www.delphidigital.io/so/02N7mWeU_?cid=32549ba4-9679-4650-9fd5-c55422f3afc8#/main

Author: brucecost#6151
Content: Is LEND token currently used for governance? How does one make a proposal if they are a LEND token holder?

Author: pabloaave
Content:
> Is LEND token currently used for governance? How does one make a proposal if they are a LEND token holder?
@brucecost 
LEND token will be used to govern the protocol, we are currently working on the implementation of the governance apart from this it will be possible to be staked within the protocol to provide security/insurance to the protocol/depositors and that way earn staking rewards and fees from the protocol. Also currently LEND token is burnt based on the fees gathered in the protocol, so holders benefit on the reduction of the supply. We are working to release the specific documentation about tokenomics and governance for more details. Meanwhile this article may be helpful:
https://www.delphidigital.io/so/02N7mWeU_?cid=32549ba4-9679-4650-9fd5-c55422f3afc8#/main

Author: pabloaave
Content: the details are about to come @brucecost Im sharing some information meanwhile

Author: Zaiga#3253
Content: Why are you diluting the Tokens by the swap? You wann swap and increase the total amount!?

Author: abertog
Content:
On the Aavenomics proposal, 100% of the new tokens will be used to strengthen the Aave ecosystem through security and liquidity incentives. Only a certain amount of tokens will be allocate to this periodically based on the community vote, the rest will be kept in the ecosystem reserve off the markets. 
The aims are to
1. protect the protocol depositors in case of deficit
2. reward protocol users
-> Basically bring more users and more security to Aave, this should benefit $AAVE holders

@Puniaviision Aave holders would decide on the policies yes, as if a market wants to be under the ecosystem benefits would need to fit on those, then also there are market specific policies on which decide the market participants/liquidity providers etc, as long as those fit the protocol policies there is space to customize the parameters, all this is yet to be defined along the addition of governance and coming votings

Author: clesaege#6512
Content:
Hi everyone,

Following the expressed need of decentralized risk teams evaluating assets to be listed as collateral, here is an Aave Request for Comments (ARC) on a proposal to use the Token¬≤ Curated Registry as part of a due diligence process before listing new assets.

Feel free to provide comments on the forum thread or on the google doc.
https://governance.aave.com/t/arc-listing-due-diligence-with-the-kleros-t2cr/1363

Author: theo__#9243
Content:
1/ [Stop the LEND burning and start building an AAVE governance treasury](https://governance.aave.com/t/proposal-to-stop-the-lend-burning-and-start-building-an-aave-governance-treasury/1012) 

- On the long term, the efficient management of Aave reserve will probably be the key part of having a self-sustainable protocol. Reserve could be use to : add an other fund to protect from hacks, grants for builders, finance long term development, etc.
- AIP-2 has been drafted to settle the foundations of this governance treasury.

Content: The total supply of AAVE is 16M, of which 13M are redeemable by LEND holders with a ratio of 100 LEND per 1 AAVE. Author: gauravsc#3827
Content: LDR (loan to deposit) ratio for a bank to make money should be 80-90%, but it‚Äôs only 20% for aave. Are there any plans to increase utilisation? Because at 20% aave will barely make money to pay back depositors.

Author: Miles#3311
Content: Can a kind soul point me in the right direction of a graph that shows the likelihood of a shortfall event on Aave?

Author: Miles#3311
Content: or perhaps one or two or multiple individual metrics to look at to get a sense of how safe one's dig assets are

Author: pikpikachu#4485
Content: The interest rates given to the depositors depends on the level of borrowing. If no one borrows then the interest rate will be close to zero. The aave governance doesn't pay anything out of its pocket to the depositors

Author: gauravsc#3827
Content: That wasn‚Äôt the question. A bank makes profits of x-y by taking x money from borrowers and paying y money to depositors. Now, if you have very little borrowing, like aave, your x-y is close to 0, which means no profits. X-Y for aave right now seems to be $10k/ week and that‚Äôs very small. And it‚Äôs small because only 20% of all money is lended out. Note: I skipped flash loan income for simplicity.

Author: gauravsc#3827
Content: If you look at the governance fund, which is the ‚Äòprofits‚Äô of aave, you‚Äôll find only $250k in it, and it increases by roughly $10k each week.

Author: pikpikachu#4485
Content: Why worry about borrowings? People will borrow it they get loans at cheap interest rates. I think the focus should be on increasing deposits which will reduce the rates of borrowing

Author: gauravsc#3827
Content: Rates will only come down when more money is borrowed, right now only 20% is borrowed, there is no lack of money even now. If utilisation doesn‚Äôt increases, more deposits will not lead to reduced rate of borrowings.

Author: gauravsc#3827
Content: No they won‚Äôt borrow just because they get loans at cheap rates, and if they get loans at cheap rates then depositors will get cheap rates and they‚Äôll not be interested in depositing money in the protocol. Most people I know don‚Äôt want to deposit already because interest rates are too low. Plus you can‚Äôt bring down rates below traditional banking rates because then people will just cash out and deposit money in the bank.

Author: gauravsc#3827
Content: Interest rate of depositing/lending will always move together, but utilisation must become larger than 80%

Author: matthew_graham
Content: Does Aave still buy back and burn AAVE tokens from the flash loan fees ? If not, can someone direct me to which AIP this was voted to change ?

Author: pabloaave
Content: @MatthewGraham https://app-v1.aave.com/governance/2-QmTSCQiNWJ3iVGvs4L4mVoLGP84UvGgcrrWi6uxhrcbj7X

Author: pikpikachu#4485
Content: Interest rates depend on the forces of demand and supply. The demand is not in our control but the supply is. We can bring down the interest rates of deposits to bring down the interest rates of borrowings.

Author: pikpikachu#4485
Content: Interest rates on deposits of stablecoins right now is around 5-10% which is extremely high compared to banks. They have like 0.5-1% interest rate on deposits. There's just the smart contract risk which slowly goes away as time passes. And the gas fee problem for which we need L2 asap

Author: pikpikachu#4485
Content: The interest rates of deposits is also not in our control but it will come down as deposits grow

Author: gauravsc#3827
Content: Interest rates for deposits/borrowings can only move together, but if you have high utilisation then you can bring borrowing rates lower without decreasing deposit rates, or in other words you can decrease the gap between the two, so again, utilisation must must must increase, period.

Author: gauravsc#3827
Content: If you‚Äôre saying that aave doesn‚Äôt have any idea or plans to increase utilisation then I understand that, but that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not important. I specifically wanted to know if there are any plans or estimates to grow utilisation üòä

Author: gauravsc#3827
Content: Nope, it doesn‚Äôt do that since AIP3 (or 2) I think. They simply put the money in a reserve fund.

Content:

Author: zer0dot
Content:
ARC: Aave Request for Comment (Done before an AIP!)

AIP: Aave Improvement Proposal (What's actually proposed to governance)

Author: zer0dot
Content: Required AAVE to submit an AIP is different depending on the executor, if you're proposing a change to the underlying infrastructure of the Aave protocol (token, safety module, governance) you'll need 2% of the supply delegated to you, if you're only changing or adding a currency/market, then you need 0.5%

Author: behold_stonksman
Content: Hello, I see that an AIP must be submitted by ‚Äúcommunity member with enough proposition power‚Äù. What is "proposition power"?

Author: leimi06
Content:
AAVE and/or stkAAVE token holders receive governance powers proportionally to the sum of their balance. There are initially two powers associated with each governance token:

1- The proposal power that gives access to creating and sustaining a proposal.

2- The voting power which is used to vote for or against existing proposals.

Any user can choose to delegate one or both of the governance powers associated with a token, either through our governance portal or programmatically.

https://docs.aave.com/governance/#governance-power

Author: corbpage
Content: A couple reasons why adding Filecoin to Aave makes sense:

Author: corbpage
Content: 1Ô∏è‚É£ If we're going to build new social networks or even a whole new internet on DeFi rails, we're going to need content storage with Filecoin.

Author: corbpage
Content: 2Ô∏è‚É£ Data DAOs, DAO hosting websites on Filecoin (truly decentralized stack), etc are only possible if we have solid financial services (Aave) integrated.

Author: corbpage
Content: 3Ô∏è‚É£ Composability -> Filecoin is sponsoring tons of hackathons and investing in their developer ecosystem. These developers NEED DeFi integrations like Aave to build truly innovative applications. A new Tachyon accelerator for Filecoin is starting soon...

Author: corbpage
Content: Thank you for any support! üôè

Author: gsmee#7359
Content: Can anyone eli5 the difference between providing liquidity and liquidity mining?

Author: Deleted User
Content:
providing liquidity -> you add assets to a protocol and receive whatever the protocol is paying for that (swap fee for pools, apy for lending, etc.)

liquidity mining -> you do the same but the project is incentivizing you by giving out extra rewards, usually in the form of emissions of some governance token, so i guess the term relates to  you somehow 'mining' those rewards

Author: raynharr
Content:
Sure, so without hogging the thread, Tellor has active staking/dispute mechanisms which give it the built-in crypto-economic security. 

We‚Äôre seeing ideas starting to evolve about mixing oracles to reduce oracle risk. An example being Liquity‚Äôs oracle design where Tellor is used as a fallback to Chainlink.

Not here to shill as much as discuss options though. The oracle landscape is still evolving and we‚Äôre just trying to spur thought on oracle risks in general. (Check the Compound & Uniswap gov threads).

Content: hey guys, so the Synthetix Ambassadors decided to wait on adding sUSD to the current liquidity mining program, and we won't be proposing to enable sUSD as collateral either (for the time being).

Author: bimabongard
Content: Hi everyone, I have a question about governance. Are Aave v2 proposals still submitted (and executed?) by the Genesis team, or the DAO has been governed in CompoundDAO style already?

Author: abertog
Content: Latest proposals are coming from the community, you can check the author of each proposal in https://app.aave.com/governance

Author: bimabongard
Content: Thank you for the link, so the proto-governance stage is over? What about execution of these proposals? How are they executed?

Author: abertog
Content:
The governance power comes from AAVE or StkAAVE Tokens with the possibility to delegate either or both proposal and voting power
First proposals need to be submitted via the Aave Github, to submit on chain you need to have collected a certain amount of proposition power 80k AAVE/stkAAVE for minor changes short timelock changes, and 320k AAVE/stkAAVE for long timelocks changes
Then it goes up for a vote on the Aave app, for a proposal to pass it needs to reach the quorum of 320k votes for
Then it can be executed by interacting with the contract on etherscan 
This is all explained in the docs https://docs.aave.com/developers/protocol-governance

Content:
Hi, I'm creating a spread derivative DeFi protocol.

Would this be even possible and how I would go to propose this to the governance ?

Appart for me this is a good thing for aave as this will create new loaning fees for people who provide LP tokens (instead of just being used as collateral).

Author: pabloaave
Content: You mean adding new assets to AMM market? that would need to go over governance proposal

Author: arikiry
Content:
On the Official Chainlink Keepers article shared early June I've been told a task could be:

"Liquidate undercollateralized loans"

I was wondering how this may look like in practice.

Couldn't the liquidation be executed atomically from the pool and redistributed to that same pool among share holders? 

This would create a powerful feedback loop reinforcing the rest of positions as colateral would go up on each liquidation instead of random 3rd party.

Not sure if I'm missing something as this looks very exciting, yet haven't heard too much talk for this specific use case.

Author: 0xcredence
Content:
Hi been an observer of defi lending for quite some time, finally decided to get my feet wet with some actual money into the protocol. 

Just a question about the lending/borrowing, is it possible to identify which the exact loan amount for every borrower/lender ?

Author: abertog
Content:
Absolutely! Its all on the blockchain üôÇ 
You can use the Aave Subgraph https://docs.aave.com/developers/getting-started/using-graphql
Or you can check the holders of each of the tokens: aTokens and debt tokens detailed here with etherscan or the covalent API https://docs.aave.com/developers/deployed-contracts/deployed-contracts

Author: 0xcredence
Content: Thank you!

Author: jorropo
Content: No, I like to enable loaning AMM tokens (which it seems to me you currently can't).

Author: abertog
Content: Yeah in the AMM configuration LP tokens are only enabled as collateral not as borrow asset (why would anyone borrow an LP token that's accruing fees ? better to just borrow the underlying assets)

Author: jorropo
Content:
> why would anyone borrow an LP token that's accruing fees ? better to just borrow the underlying assets
No, because I'm doing spread, basically I want to short impermanent loss.
To do so I need to borrow LP tokens, then unpack them and add the underlying as collateral.

Like the whole point of IL is that you loose money compared to someone who is holding the underlying assets, let's assume this is longing IL.
Well, I want to short IL, so I do the reverse (borrow LP tokens and deposit underlying), then if IL kicks in I'll win money compared to the one holding LP tokens.

Author: Lander#6532
Content: Yeah, that seems quite important to keep the incentive going.

Author: jorropo
Content: (the actual thing isn't as simple, because with this example you would still loose money if both assets goes down in price, so you need to fully edge your underlying and only expose the spread, but it's doable)

Author: abertog
Content: THanks for the explaination, sounds like you need to share your situation in the forum with an ARC, its up to the governance to activate borrowing on those assets

Author: Deleted User
Content:
To weigh in on the whole BOND debate, I think it's entirely reasonable to vote 'nay' on the proposal. Bond is a great asset, and their relationship with Aave is mutually beneficial, but enabling it to be used as collateral would be risky. 

Bond has a low market cap, and not a lot of liquidity, and allowing loans to be collateralized with bond could potentially result in loans becoming undercollatoralized

Author: inkymaze | Gauntlet#0850
Content:
Thank you for explaining your rationale here. We would like to highlight that liquidity mining or adding additional assets have similar difficulties. Does liquidity mining drive only short-term growth? Does adding additional assets add tail risk to the protocol? Yes, they drive protocol revenue but how much is tough to pinpoint. All protocol changes will face this difficulty and that is why we called out metrics where we can drive the most impact.

One thing from most previous AIPs is clear, the Aave community has a long-term vision and is willing to experiment in the short term. Governance can and should evaluate Gauntlet‚Äôs impact quarterly and decide whether to renew our engagement.

Author: retrodigital#0531
Content:
Sorry, in proposals adding additional asset like PAX or AMPL I could not find any fee calculations like yours.
You say yourself it is difficult to determine the benefit, but you are very precise in calculating the fees. And how should the Aave stakeholders should evaluate quarterly the benefits of Gauntlet?

Author: inkymaze | Gauntlet#0850
Content:
- Risk-adjusted yield for Depositors
- Capital efficiency for Borrowers
- Mitigate Depositor losses

Gauntlet will improve the metrics above without increasing the net insolvent value percentage or the slashing run percentage.

Author: retrodigital#0531
Content: Three metrics good for depositors, borrowers and which one for the stakeholders to calculate the benefit of 8 Mio plus invest per year? Your high fee approach is not the best idea for selling a good idea.

Author: n1tro1136

Author: hillbilly_chess
Content:
"Gauntlet charges a service fee that seeks to be commensurate with the value we add to protocols." I didn't see any detail to the actual financial value of gauntlet we would realize if Aave holders hired Gauntlet. We should hire you b/c you can show we should have  lower liquidation bonuses for some assets?  What happens if you don't improve the Risk Adjusted Yield or Capital efficiency for borrowers. I would support a compensation plan that makes sense, has actual financial targets that you guys need to hit to get paid. Otherwise you are fleecing us! 
Nobody would hire a consultant without firm financial targets to get compensated. Why is that not in this proposal? This propsosal has 0 recourse if you fail to do what you promise here.

Author: inkymaze | Gauntlet#0850
Content: Yes, they are measurable as we have done in the proposal. Creating controls and treatments and observing outputs is what we do to sanity check our models.

Content: Great call out. This https://gauntlet.network/reports/aave is the equivalent of a code review. What we are proposing is continuous

Author: asdpc
Content:
This is a common issue with dapps that initiate transactions that you then need to approve using your Metamask or whatever: that won't work for multisigs like Gnosis Safe and the like.

An old workaround that has done the trick for me in other dapps is initiating the transaction with my own account on Metamask, and instead of submitting the transaction, I look at the data field and copypaste those hex bytes into a new multisig transaction pointing to the same contract address and containing the same data. Once the signing is done by the required signers, the transaction that goes through should be perfectly valid.

Author: abertog
Content:
The Aave community has been using snapshot to gauge the community sentiment and preferred choice for the on chain governance proposal 
Snapshot support multi chains and also multi tokens more details in their docs https://docs.snapshot.org/

Author: abertog
Content: Snapshot votes are for gathering community sentiment so there is no quorum requirement. It helps define the content for the on chain AIP. You can find more details on proposals and voting requirements on the GitHub https://github.com/aave/governance-v2

Hi, please help me

Author: pabloaave
Content: You can migrate from LEND to AAVE at https://app-v1.aave.com -> migration portal

Author: pabloaave
Content:
Make sure to have ETH for the transaction cost.

There are also alternative services allowing the migration as:

https://www.myetherwallet.com/interface/dapps/lend-migrator

https://app.mycrypto.com/migrate/aave

Over Binance (access might depend on your residency) that allow LEND deposits and conversion to AAVE.
https://www.binance.com/en/support/announcement/17595222999545348c8acdd5dc41c00a

If you are elegible the cheaper option is likely to be over Binance.

Author: Anika | she256#6692
Content: Hi everyone, I lead governance initiatives at¬†she256¬†(https://she256.org/) and we‚Äôre hoping to get involved with Aave as one of our first protocols! We are a 501c3 run by crypto-natives that are dedicated to increasing diversity in the blockchain space. Our approach is to facilitate discussions on new proposals for our community and represent a range of voices in our voting decisions. After an initial call with the Aave team, we were advised to reach out here with a formal request for delegation. If anyone here is open to delegating governance tokens to she256, please contact me and we can discuss further. We hope to work with some of you!

Content:
hey all - would anyone familiar with the ARC Risk Parameter Update process be willing to advise on a proposal?

I'm an Index Coop contributor and we're looking to launch a leveraged 2x MATIC token (similar to the FLI tokens on L1) that uses Aave Polygon on the backend. However, the Max LTV for MATIC is prohibitive so we'd like to request that the LTV be raised to 65%. I want to be respectful of the process and risks though so if anyone would be willing to support, we would greatly appreciate it!

Content:
Hi @Pablo Won't DM you first

I was going through this article recently https://uncommoncore.co/a-new-mental-model-for-defi-treasuries/ and had a couple of questions regarding how the Aave treasury is being managed currently and its expenditure etc? 

My main questions are:
1. As per OpenOrgs (https://openorgs.info/), Aave currently has $551 million of Aave tokens in the treasury. Where can I find the the monthly expenditure of the treasury?  (Note: In the financial reports submitted by Llama here (https://governance.aave.com/t/aave-treasury-report/5575/8), operating expenses is blank for both September & October 21 reports)
2. I know Aave company & Aave protocol are different, so is Aave protocol treasury used to fund Aave company operations or is it done separately from VC funding etc?

I'm planning to raise a discussion thread on treasury management in the Aave governance forum and so wanted to understand the basics of Aave treasury before doing that.

Thanks

Author: lucianken
Content:
Few questions I haven't found the answer in the docs. 
1. What's the scope of the emergency admin power? Who are the emergency admin signers?
2. How can emergency admins be overrulled? 
3. Why there are no docs about this kind of info?
4. Is the fallback oracle mantained and live?
5. Are there any kind of delays on governance votes for users to withdraw their assets before they go live?

Author: shiv#0077
Content:
> 1. What's the scope of the emergency admin power? Who are the emergency admin signers?
emergency admin power can pause the lending pool
aave guardian elected members https://governance.aave.com/t/aave-guardian-elected-members/5772

> 2.  How can emergency admins be overrulled?
governance can set the emergency admin through the gov process and the new emergency admin can unpause
> 3. Why there are no docs about this kind of info?
the docs refer to it as guardian multisig (not explicitly mentioned as emergency admin so maybe confusing) but I agree it is not very detailed. I will update the docs, so all information is easily accessible and much clear.
> 4. Is the fallback oracle mantained and live?
The address of fallback oracle can always be queried from Price Oracle available in deployed contracts section in dev docs. The price from fallback is used only if source is 0 or price is negative. So fallback oracle prices are not actively updated rather main security focus is to keep asset price source up to date.
Anyway you can find fallback oracle here üëâüèª https://etherscan.io/address/0x5b09e578cfeaa23f1b11127a658855434e4f3e09#code
> 5. Are there any kind of delays on governance votes for users to withdraw their assets before they go live?
Delays are based on type of proposals => https://docs.aave.com/developers/protocol-governance/governance#proposal-types

Author: lucianken
Content: Hey, question what are the long timelock and short timelock values? Who decides in which lock does a proposal fall? it's a community decision? Let's say an attack puts a bad/stupid proposal that Idk sets the oracle of wbtc to 1 does this go automatically on the long lock or is this voted too during the process?

Author: shiv#0077
Content:
Which time lock the proposal should be submitted is decided by the protocol and can be updated by the community.
For eg. Only pool admin can initialize new token in Aave market and the pool admin for main v2 market on ethereum is short lock executor. So, in this case a proposal has to go through short timelock executor else it cannot be executed/have no consequence. 
Contracts are verified on etherscan so you can read the value of delay, grace period etc there. Links to all executor contracts can be found üëáüèª https://docs.aave.com/developers/protocol-governance/governance

Author: curmudgeon#3557
Content: They still can't seem to come up with a reasonable answer why they insist on staking when there's delegation built into AAVE governance. Have asked three times. At best, it creates unneeded smart contracts risk. At worst it exposed you to a rug. Either way, i fail to understand this design choice.

Author: Tim D#3701
Content: Hmmm...I'm not sure I understand the question. I thought the protocol worked like this. AAVE and stAAVE holders stake their assets in the AAVE pool on Bribe, earn back Bribe tokens as rewards, then bidders come in and bid on the voting power of entire AAVE pool. How else could bidders bid on the voting power of the pool if it wasn't staked in the protocol to extract the votes?

Author: Tim D#3701
Content: How is it any different than what Convex or Votium did with Curve?

Author: curmudgeon#3557
Content:
Votium does not require you to stake anything. They see how your address voted (visible to all) and then you collect your bribe in an airdrop like interface... You can optionally delegate your vote to votium but that is a convenience and fallback in case you forget to vote. You can vote the desired way to earn the bribe or the other way to forgo it if you feel strongly. Importantly, you as an individual are always in control of both your principal token and your vote.

No matter how badly votium goes, your cvx is never in their smart contract. Worst case is you lose earned but not collected bribe if they get hacked/exploited.

Here you stake the AAVE or stkaave in a bribe smart contract. If those are malicious or erroneous, those tokens are at risk. I see no need to organize things that way when you can delegate or vote the desired ways. So why are bribe so insistent on taking possession? They say some comment about front running that makes no sense to me. Unless their contract blocks you from withdrawing once they accept a bribe, in which case your tokens could be voting for something malicious and have no control to stop it.

Custody and additional smart contract risk should require a strong justification. With delegation and publicly visible voting, i see no good reason to do this unless they are intending to not give your tokens back until after the vote. And not bothering to clarify that in tweets or Medium. That's the most innocent explanation I could find tbh. Unless you consider sloppy laziness as more innocent which is actually worse than malice in this space.

Author: Tim D#3701
Content: Very good points. I guess the use case is a little different, because you don't actually vote. I remember reading that they were trying to gather up under utilized ve tokens, but doesn't really explain the lack of clarity or seemingly sloppy design.

Author: curmudgeon#3557
Content:
If you don't vote you don't keep control. but even so AAVE governance has a built in delegation function, so they can still vote on your behalf.

Something feels off.

Author: raho11
Content: Hey guys I have a question‚Ä¶ what exactly does the process look like when a vote is passed to change risk parameters on an asset?

Author: raho11
Content: Question here being - what happens after the vote is passed? How do the risk parameters get updated?

Author: raho11
Content: @DeFi Spartan can you help me out on this plz üôÇ

Author: mori69
Content:
the proposal triggers functions designated in the proposal payload that initiate changes in the market. governance is kind of like a gnosis safe in that you can instruct it to call any function. the governance contract is given ownership rights to the configuration contracts so that it can make the necessary changes when proposals pass. 

for the markets governed on chain, there is no way to change the markets without going through the governance process.

hi.
question about Credit Delegation.
Suppose you lend someone using Credit Deligation.

Author: pabloaave
Content: the problem would be on the delegator side, you should never delegate without trusting the party you are delegating to

Content: credit delegation relies on trust relation or binding agreement or any other kind of enforcement, for example on-chain contract acting as security for any otehr kind of collateral etc

Author: pabloaave
Content: the APR comes from certain amount per day of stkAAVE tokens that is splitted between depositors/borrowers for certain asset

Content: so basically the calculation comes from x stkAAVE / day per asset and "action" (borrow/deposit)

Content: it comes from governance decision

Author: Mathias_L#9829
Content:
Hi I have a question around the power dynamic of Aave as a platform. 

A proxy contract is used to govern the platform correct? That means every update cannot be enforced upon users. Instead  a new version is deployed and then users have to get coordinated towards using it. That eliminates the threat of web2 platforms that could enforce more and more features upon to bind us to the platform and ultimately extract way more rent than we initially anticipated. So I like the decentralised approach of course.

But it brings up the question of what tools the governance contract really has to coordinate users towards a new update. For example if Aave wants to raise its fees how would that work? Couldn't users just keep using the old version?

And also what happens once a trillion is locked in the protocol, how could updates then be implemented? How do you make a trillion move to a new updated version? 

I guess the front end is a tool to coordinate but that is in control of the team rather than the token holders right?

So how does all of that work exactly? And how will it work in the future? Or am I missing something?

Thanks in advance for any clarification

Author: Tactis#8562
Content: Hi, I am doing a research project on Aave for my financial innovations class. One of the questions relates to looking at previous snapshot votes, explaining what was being voted on, and seeing if any Aave holders hold enough to single-handedly sway a vote. As far as I can tell, one does not have to stake to vote on these things. I have figured out how to check the top 10 voters on the governance page when using AAVE classic, but none of these addresses seem to show up on the list of addresses holding Aave or staked Aave that I downloaded from the Etherscan page. Can anyone explain to me why this would be and how I would be able to determine this? If anyone can vote (or only those staking can vote), would I just be able to look at the top holders who have greater than .5% of Aave (as that seems to be the standard required amount over naes voting yes, meaning that if one person with .5% voted yae and noone voted nae, the vote could pass.

Author: eek637
Content:
Hi all - if you have a moment and have Aave delegated to you, we at Avantgarde Finance would appreciate your "YAE" vote on this proposal: https://app.aave.com/governance/proposal/?proposalId=77

If it passes, it adds a function that allows for users to claim their stkAAVE rewards without passing a `to` address as a parameter; instead the rewards are passed directly to the address that calls the function (and has earned the rewards). This change allows for Enzyme vault managers to claim rewards on behalf of their vault, but has a wider application to any set of contracts that uses the same proxy architecture.

The code this proposal implements has been audited and approved. It passed a snapshot at the end of last year (https://snapshot.org/#/aave.eth/proposal/QmcgTovk982fcUTN17qtDyZ4oCoVGnKZJGuwMVtqspfphk). A full description of the change is here, along with the code itself: https://github.com/aave/aip/blob/Pending-AIPs/content/aips/29720ED10AEA-AIP-ADD-CLAIMREWARDSTOSELF-TO-INCENTIVES.md

Author: NoDeal#1991
Content: Why can't I borrow stEth through Aave? There is a TON of stEth in the reserve, yet I can't borrow it? It will force users like me to euler.finance which is less battle-tested than aave so that is not ideal. wstETH is Euler's 3rd most borrowed asset after USDC and WETH so there is significant demand for this. On top of that, I would assume it actually improves Aave's overall safety if people can hedge and take the other side of this, as your chance of incurring bad debt due to steth would decrease? Can someone please let me know if there are plans to enable this, it just seems really bizarre to me

Author: NoDeal#1991
Content: It's kinda mind blowing, there is $2.5B of stETH in aave, it is the MOST supplied asset in the protocol, and it can't be borrowed!! usually I've been very impressed by aave's risk assessments but i'm just in awe here

Author: h3lpfulbrother
Content: At the moment stETH is only available as collateral, which is why all the supply is available to borrow. This may change through governance, feel free to propose at https://governance.aave.com

Author: NoDeal#1991
Content:
I don't have 500 aave so I can't make the proposal - but it seems absolutely crazy from the outside looking in. IIRC the justification Aave provided on twitter for this decision was "we didn't think there was going to be borrow demand for stETH". I do not believe that, and even giving you the benefit of the doubt that assumption is definitely not true now - go check euler.finance for proof - the borrow APY for wstETH is ~5.5% with $32.5M worth of it borrowed (over 50% utilization rate). 

It is so obvious this is getting into systemic risk territory (not only for aave) but other protocols built on top of aave. From your governance "Due to uncertainty around the stETH peg, Gauntlet proposes increasing stETH liquidation threshold. This will allow borrowers using stETH as collateral with more buffer in case stETH continues to depeg, and thus decrease the chances of liquidation cascades that lead to insolvency on the Aave platform" https://app.aave.com/governance/proposal/75/

What is the real explanation for not enabling borrowing on stETH. Every other large asset on your platform can be borrowed, but the largest one can't!? And there is a ton of risk around stETH - you have smart contract risk, trust assumptions, merge uncertainty (not only around if/when the merge happens, but possible forks) and you are limiting the market to weigh risk here. Maybe someone with more skin in the game can turn this into a governance proposal - totally bizarre to me

Author: hjfeldy#1353
Content:
Hi, is it correct to say that AAVE governance has control over ALL protocol reserves (as in across every network the on which the AAVE has been deployed)?

It's my understanding that voting takes place entirely on the Ethereum network, so I can't see it being any other way.

Author: hjfeldy#1353
Content: I think the formal term is *Ecosystem Reserves, not protocol reserves. Borrow interest X reserve factor

Author: pabloaave
Content: not by the grants DAO, grants DAO has certain budget to give grants but the protocol collector contract holds way more funds that can be used to more proposals to further develop the protocol etc, those can be propsoed by governance voting

Author: pabloaave
Content: Aave companies is the team that originally bringed Aave protocol, which now is fully decentralized so anyone could contribute to the protocol development and growth

Author: pabloaave
Content: certain markets can't be managed by Ethereum governance (at least yet), those are handled by the Guardians multisig, which members were decided by a governance voting over snapshot

Author: pabloaave
Content: there is an "ecosystem reserve" contract, and also several "collector contracts" holding the fees coming from the reserve factor

Author: odovich
Content: hello, guys. I have a question. What is the difference between voting on https://snapshot.org/#/aave.eth and on https://app-v3.aave.com/governance/ ? Is it enough if I only stake my AAVE? Or I also should delegate it to myself on https://app-v3.aave.com/governance/ ?

Author: pabloaave
Content: snapshot is sentiment voting, so its not a voting that would executed any change in the protocol, but AIPs (so on-chain voting, the ones showm at https://app-v3.aave.com/governance/) indeed execute changes in the protocol

Author: pabloaave
Content: you should be able to vote and/or delegate with stkAAVE

Content: It depends on what you refer with Aave Team, if you refer to Aave companies, as a company it has its own structure and decision making, if you are referring to Aave protocol, as its decentralized there is no official team, anyone could basically contribute to the protocol and even get monetary or any other resources from a governance proposal, there are already several governance proposals like this, some examples might be Aave grants DAO team, BGD Labs, Certora, Gauntlet etc

Author: lveiga#8463
Content:
hey Guys, morning!

I'm thinking to move some AAVE from layer two to layer one and stake it (since gas fees are low)
few questions here:
1 - I will be subject to impermanent loss in order to get the ABP Token right?
2 - how many transactions / gas fees it takes to complete the operation? Get the liquidity token and complete the steps to stake on AAVE?

Author: lveiga#8463
Content: not sure if this is the correct channel, I'm sorry for that

Author: pabloaave
Content: ABPT as you are depositing in BalancerAAVE/ETH 85/15 then indeed there might be impermanent loss as in any AMM, you have just AAVE staking option if you wish to avoid this

Author: pabloaave
Content: 2 - not fully sure, in terms of transactions usually would be creating the proxy for the pool in balancer, then approve both assets (wrap ETH to WETH if needed too) deposit into Balancer, then stake BPT into staking contract (approval required too here)

Author: pabloaave
Content: for normal staking is just approve AAVE, stake AAVE

Author: lveiga#8463
Content: so probably at least ~ half a dozen transactions, but the approval ones should be less expensives, right?

Author: lveiga#8463
Content: gas fees are reasonable right now, but still don't want to have a big surprise after moving the assets

Author: pabloaave
Content: approvals are usually quite cheap in comparison with other kind of more complex transactions

Author: pabloaave
Content: sending ETH is around 22K gas, approvals might be from 50K to 100K or around that

Author: pabloaave
Content: so usually 2x to 5x what cost sending ETH

Content:
Hey everyone! 

I'm writing to ask for your support in adding :MAI: MAI to Aave V3 on Polygon. MAI is a stablecoin that is fully overcollateralized by 60+ collaterals, and we believe that it would be a valuable addition to the Aave V3 platform. 

MAI is already available on a number of other major chains and dexes, and we believe that adding it to Aave V3 would increase growth exposure and liquidity. We would be grateful for your support in this matter üôè 

Worth mentioning that MAI has no exposure to USDC and other centralized stablecoins.

üó≥Ô∏è  The proposal ends **08/26/2022 10:43 PM **and is available here: https://app.aave.com/governance/proposal/?proposalId=93

Content: Thank you üíØ

Author: bpgamma
Content:
Hey guys, I'm Brian from Gamma Strategies, which is an active Uniswap v3 manager.  

If anyone is interested, I am writing a draft proposal (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lAHjZx8m4J-meswzTk1BypxIAZum-W-GQfurEHPn7U0/edit) for Aave that will allow the GHO-USDC LP position on Uniswap v3 to be allowed as collateral for GHO in an isolated lending market.

The ability to leverage yield farm this LP position has the potential to garner significant liquidity for GHO-USDC which helps its peg and will generate revenue for the DAO.  And the isolated lending market is an extra layer of precaution against depeg events or manipulation.

Happy to discuss further and get feedback from the community!  Much appreciated.

Author: jam1931
Content:
Hello Aave community - Trying to do some market survey from a mature DAO like Aave (plz dont ban me üôè ). 

What do people think about a partially anonymous forum? Has anyone censored their controversial ideas due to fear of social reprisals? What have you done if your idea goes against the big players in the DAO? Can partial anonymity be a way to start addressing group think?

I understand that social reputation is important in qualifying the ideas but, it also gets in the way of viewing ideas based on its merits. In certain cases, we censor our controversial comments because it goes against the grain of the majority of DAOs and we tend to not point that out because of fear of social reprisal. Again, this may get in the way of having the most effective decision as some ideas are not considered (and that ‚Äúconsensus‚Äù is a more of a capitulation than general agreement that we have the best idea.)

I believe that certain topics may require an anon space to assess the ideas by its merits rather than rely too heavily on the social representation (albeit it has an important role in the DAO). 

How do you think anon forums would impact the quality of forum discussions?

Author: nonstoptheo
Content:
Hi y'all - published this write-up in the forum last week but didn't get much feedback.

It's a risk-related topic: How can we get standardized trade volume stats for asset onboarding + risk mgmt.

Sounds trivial , but it's not. Looking thru onboarding proposals, most use the aggregate CoinGecko number (which incl CEXes with low trust scores). Wash trading is an issue and we don't need to accept the existing, substandard approaches.

https://governance.aave.com/t/standardizing-trade-volume-reporting-for-aaves-asset-onboarding-risk-management-processes/10429

Author: defispartan
Content: This proposal will not have an effect on existing positions. Freezing an asset disables new supplies/borrows and disabling borrowing only disables new borrows. Freezing or disabling borrowing has no effect on current supply/borrow positions, ability to repay/withdraw, or usage of an asset as collateral

Author: pabloaave
Content: AAVE token as it init acted as governance token, so since AAVE token inception it was already governed by AAVE holders, governance decision upon AAVE token inception bringed 3M AAVE allocation to the ecosystem reserve of the protocol that basically acted as the first treasury by the DAO

Author: juanlopes
Content:
Grants subdao was created at the same time that AAVE DAO? 
How was the process to choose the committee members? Who they are?
Board members have "special rights" on gov/grants proposals?

Author: pabloaave
Content: grants DAO was proposal 13 from decentralized governance here https://app.aave.com/governance/proposal/13/

Author: pabloaave
Content: in May 2021

Author: pabloaave
Content: initial thread by them at https://governance.aave.com/t/arc-aave-community-grants-program/3642 in April 2021

Author: juanlopes
Content:
Ohh got it
So just after the rebranding the token was governance token? When it's was LEND wasn't it?

Author: pabloaave
Content: LEND token technically speaking was limited in the ability to act as governance token, but the migration to AAVE token was decided by LEND holders over decentralized governance mechanism too

Author: juanlopes
Content: Nice, since day one of LEND token AAVE (ETHLend) was a DAO, right?

Author: pabloaave
Content: it became governance upon the transition to AAVE as per the decision by LEND holders, but in previous times was more oriented to be used in ETHLend ecosystem

Author: julieholdim
Content:
Greetings Aave Community!

We understand that your time is valuable and want to invite you to join the beta and download our Holdim app. With Holdim, you can easily stay up to date on the proposals of various DAOs. All the tl;drs will be presented in the form of feed and you can check active proposals whenever and wherever you have a few minutes of free time.

We are currently in the beta phase and are offering limited downloads with a unique reward for the first few explorers. Not only will you be able to try out the latest features, but you will also receive an exclusive POAP token as a token of our appreciation. All you need to do is log in with a public key - yours or Vitalik's!

So don't wait any longer, download Holdim and stay up to date on DAO proposals.

Download link for IOS users¬†https://testflight.apple.com/join/z2Uf0Uz9

Author: rexdefisafety
Content:
DeFiSafety is evolving from just publishing ratings on DeFi protocols to issuing safety certificates and we need the support of protocols like AAVE.  We can‚Äôt go into the next bull run expecting investors to DYOR on protocol safety.   We have been reviewing AAVE since we started in June 2020.  Updates were done in July 2021 and Mar 2022.  We ask AAVE to purchase a certificate and support the creation of certificates.

What is the best way to start this conversation?  A forum post?  If so, what category?  Thanks.

I have stupid question: 
We have two labs - Chaos labs and Gauntlet. I see a lot of proposals by both of them on changes in parameters of AAVE protocol. 
What will happen if both of them submit different suggestions (even in different directions) at the same time and both of them will be accepted on the governance vote?

Author: Ivan#3199

P.S. Both suggest bullshit = Reject both.

Content: The minimum is 0.5 AAVE

Author: imdior.eth
Content:
@h3lpfulBrother
We are trying to find the best model for our delegation process, so we are researching information about governance, DAO and delegation.

1. How many active delegates do you have? How their vote power is distributed? 
2. What are the stats of Delegate involvement (i.e. voting, percentage of token supply delegated, number of proposals voted on). Do you track this?
3. Does Delegation help you to solve Governance problems? Is anyone doing something surprising with Delegates? Is something that you would like to improve or change?
4. How did DAO ‚Äòtrack‚Äô and communicate about Delegate involvement? (i.e with tooling etc)
5. What is your assessment of the interfaces/tooling that community members can use to elect Delegates (i.e. ease for token holders to delegate, ease for delegates, how much do these interfaces affect the utilization of Delegates).
6. How do you involve the community to delegate? (This is not easy to convince them).
7. How you engage with your community (not delegates or entities)? I suppose that via Governance call. Any advise, help, suggestions how can be improved the governance call and how to engage more community in it ? üôÇ

Some of the questions i already found via your forum and tools, but would be great if you could answer them anyway. Maybe i missed something or you can point me out something relevant that i missed.

Author: pabloaave
Content: Hello @Imdior_CKZ | CFG it would be more appropiate to reach contributors to the DAO that specifically work on those fronts, as maybe llama team, aave grants dao, chaos labs, gauntlet etc, but regarding your questions, most of the things you ask you can query them directly using tools as dune analytics or directly on-chain, delegation is an on-chain action and you can easily query those events to do those analysis

-  Does Delegation help you to solve Governance problems?
and etc...

Content: but Im not really understanding the reasoning to ask a specific team when Aave protocol is decentralized and not ruled or owned by us, basically AAVE holders govern Aave protocol, Aave protocol governance delegation is something in line with the DAO strategy and that is not decided by any specific team but by decentralized governance, anyone is able to delegate their voting via app.aave.com or directly interacting with Aave protocol contracts

Author: pabloaave
Content: in addition anyone can postulate themselves to become a delegatee people usually do that in the governance forum

Content: there is even a section for it at https://governance.aave.com/c/delegate-platforms/27

> but Im not really understanding the reasoning to ask a specific team when Aave protocol is decentralized and not ruled or owned by us

Author: marczeller
Content:
Hello @Imdior_CKZ | CFG answering as Aave Chan initiative the main Aave DAO delegate.

The Aave companies still work on Aave protocol but is now more focused on tech breakthrough implementation (V3, portals, GHO) and has been slowly and soundly diluted over the years by the Aave DAO for the "Day2day" management of the protocol

Author: marczeller
Content:
There's around a dozen of active delegates 
You can easily find them in the delegate platform section of the governance forum

Author: marczeller
Content: And in the vote results

Author: marczeller
Content:
On top of that, you have specialized service providers working on the Aave DAO:

The ACI and Llama are focused on building AIP, risk parameters, asset management, treasury management and more

Gauntlet and chaos labs are risk managers and are focused on keeping Aave safe and work on risk parameters

Bgdlabs are Aave DAO core developpers

And Aave grant DAO... Well it's in the name

Author: marczeller
Content: Anybody can create a delegate platform, campaign for vote delegation, or do a proposal to become a compensated service provider for the DAO

Author: marczeller
Content: The money comes from the actual economical activity of the protocol, when ppl borrow on Aave they pay interest on their debt, part of these interests are collected by the aave DAO

Author: marczeller
Content: You have community tools such as boardroom to follow DAO delegate activity

Author: marczeller
Content: U have dune dashboards to track that as well

Author: marczeller
Content: Usually that info is accessible In delegate platform

Author: marczeller
Content: Hope that answer most of your questions, the rest... Well data is public, it's the Blockchain feel free to DYOR

Question about how to vote: I have AAVE on Matic, I am a LP there. But I also want to vote with my AAVE. Is it correct that on-chain voting is only on ETH?

2. Your Aave just needs to be there before the vote starts, once voted you can move it back.

Author: Scienity (Ahmed)#9043
Content:
Hello @everyone, I'm Ahmed from Canada, I have been looking at the granting review process and was wondering if I could DM someone on the granting committee to offer a tool that may help improve the granting process.

I work with Ethelo - a collective decision-making platform and we have been working with some DAOs (e.g Gitcoin and BigGreen DAO) to help with collective decision-making for their granting process with our multi-criteria decision platform. 

Here is an example template, for those that are interested: https://granting.ethelo.net/ 
The platform is very flexible and can be configured to fit all sorts of decision matrices, and I think it might be useful to your granting process. 

Thank you! üôè

Author: antolove
Content:
Hello,

After having exchanged with your bot regarding the need to use a governance token to avoid purchasing Ethereum and paying fees on your platform, thus enabling us to transfer our funds or Aave tokens directly to your platform without incurring any charges and allowing us to stake or perform other actions, it advised me to communicate this to you, so here I am.

Hoping that you can find a solution.

Looking forward to your response,

Best regards.

Author: h3lpfulbrother
Content: Please open a ticket in #üôãsupport  (on this server)

Author: h3lpfulbrother
Content:
There is no way to avoid paying network fees for transactions, you can use AAVE for a discount on the interest rate when borrowing GHO.

If you want to pay less network fees select a cheaper networ like Polygon or Arbitrum.

Author: evren001
Content:
Hello all. I'm currently researching DAO governance models and reading AAVE governance documents. I have a few questions regarding and really appreciate if any member can share some feedback.

As per my understanding, AAVE currently employs the governance v2 model. I noticed that a proposal for Aave governance v3 was voted on Snapshot two weeks ago, but an AIP or on-chain voting has not taken place yet. Should I consider Aave governance v2 as the latest document for my reference? https://docs.aave.com/developers/v/2.0/protocol-governance/governance#proposal-life-cycle

Regarding to Snapshot, as as per v2 documents, Snapshot voting is optional but highly recommended for consensus. However, within Snapshot settings, there is a min quorum set at 320K as well as 3 day voting period + 1 day voting delay. Since snapshot voting is not mandatory, I'm wondering how relevant this quorum and durations? Also historically, there are several snapshot votings took more than 5 days. Was there any update in 2023 regarding to duration?

Regarding to onchain voting, Level2 requirements are updated with proposal 106 - https://app.aave.com/governance/proposal/106/ - could you please confirm?

Sorry to ask many questions, but the confusion is that there are several documentations, not clear which one is the latest . so proposal 106 lowers the proposition threshold, quorum and vote differentials for long executor proposals, right?

Author: h3lpfulbrother
Content: Hey thanks for the questions, although we have a governance channel lol these are now best suited for the governance forum where discussions around governance mechanics take place.

Author: h3lpfulbrother
Content: You can find this  at https://docs.aave.com/risk/

Author: h3lpfulbrother
Content: https://app.aave.com/governance/ - connect your wallet and you can see who you are currently delegating to.

Author: evren001
Content: thanks for reply. Yes, I already checked governance forum, went through some of the discussions.

Author: h3lpfulbrother
Content:
gm fam,
Many of the questions asked here lately are being redirected to the governance forums because that is where the conversations are happening.

If you have any governance questions we encourage you to search and ask on the governance forums. Thanks! :superhero:
